case_name: Managing Committee T. K. Ghoshs Academy v. The two sons of Shri Jadu Nath Palit

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 570 of 1969 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 570 of 1969. From the Judgment and decree dated the 29th September, 1967 of the Patna High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 459 of 1961.

facts.text: The appeal is from the Judgment and decree dated 29th September 1967 of the Patna High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 459 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: From the Judgment and decree dated the 29th September, 1967 of the Patna High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 459 of 1961.

facts.text: Additional Sub Judge Patna awarded decree for ejectment and recovery of Rs. 7,163/12/3 to two plaintiff-respondents against Board of Trustees T. K. Ghoshs Academy Patna and other defendants.

anchor.surface_text: A decree for ejectment from the premises in dispute and for recovery of Rs. 7,163/12/3 was awarded by learned Additional Sub Judge Patna in favour of the two plaintiff-respondents, against the Board of Trustees T. K. Ghoshs Academy Patna and other defendants.

facts.text: Patna High Court set aside the decree for ejectment on appeal filed by some defendants.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal filed by some of the defendants the Patna High Court set aside the decree for ejectment.

facts.text: Patna High Court reduced the decreed amount to Rs. 3,725/2/- .

anchor.surface_text: The amount for the recovery of which decree had been awarded by the trial court was also reduced to Rs. 3,725/2/- .

facts.text: Present appeal filed on certificate by Managing Committee T. K. Ghoshs Academy and other defendants against High Court decision.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal has been filed on certificate by the Managing Committee T. K. Ghoshs Academy and other defendants against the decision of the High Court.

facts.text: Shri Jadu Nath Palit founded T. K. Ghoshs Academy in 1876.

anchor.surface_text: The two plaintiff-respondents are the sons of Shri Jadu Nath Palit who founded in 1876 a school known as T. K. Ghoshs Academy.

facts.text: Shri Jadu Nath Palit died in 1901 leaving three minor sons including two plaintiff-respondents and Dr. K. Palit.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Jadu Nath died in 1901 leaving behind three minor sons, two of whom were the plaintiff-respondents and the third was their brother Dr. K. Palit.

facts.text: Managing Committee formed by sons of T. K. Ghosh in 1905 or 1906.

anchor.surface_text: A Managing Committee was formed by the sons of T. K. Ghosh for the management of the school in 1905 or 1906.

facts.text: On September 11, 1919 the three sons of Shri Jadu Nath purchased the school building from Mr. Boilard per sale deed Ex.C.

anchor.surface_text: On September 11, 1919 the school building was purchased by the three sons of Shri Jadu Nath from Mr. Boilarld as per sale deed Ex.C.

facts.text: On July 28, 1930 Dr. K. L Palit sold his share in the school building to his two brothers per sale deed Ex.Cl.

anchor.surface_text: On July 28, 1930 Dr. K. L Palit sold his share in the school building in favour of his two brothers, viz-, the plaintiff-respondents, as per sale deed Ex.Cl.

facts.text: On August 13, 1950 the two plaintiff-respondents executed Deed of Trust Ex.P appointing trustees.

anchor.surface_text: On August 13, 1950 the two plaintiff-respondents executed Deed of Trust. Ex.P appointing Rai Bahadur Nirmal Chandra Ghosh, Retired District and Sessions Judge and six others as trustees of the school.

facts.text: Deed of Trust provided trustees to shift school to new premises within 5 years and vacate present premises to settlors.

anchor.surface_text: The trustees shall find other premises for the location of the school and shift the school there within 5  five  years of the date of the deed and vacate the present premises to the settlors.

facts.text: Deed of Trust provided settlors receive house rent of Rs. 250 per month for 5 years.

anchor.surface_text: The settlors will receive a house rent of Rs. 250/per month for the said period of 5  five  years for the premises number occupied by the school as owners of the premises.

facts.text: School building extended to holding No. 22 in 1951.

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated that the school building initially stood on holding No. 20. In 1951 the building was extended to holding No. 22 also.

facts.text: Plaintiffs claimed agreement for rent of Rs. 37/8/- for holding No. 22, total rent Rs. 287/8/- .

anchor.surface_text: According to the plaintiff- respondents, it was agreed that they would be paid a rent of Rs. 37/8/- for the building on holding No. 22. The total rent thus came to Rs. 287/8/-

facts.text: In June 1956 trustees and Managing Committee settled with consent of plaintiffs: Rs. 190/- direct to plaintiffs, balance Rs. 97/8/- to trustees for taxes and repairs.

anchor.surface_text: It is further the case of the plaintiffs that in or about June 1956 it was settled by the trustees and the Managing Committee of the school with the companysent of the plaintiffs that out of the monthly rent of Rs. 287/8/- a cash amount of Rs. 190/- would be paid directly to the plaintiffs and the balance,of Rs. 97/8/-

facts.text: Premises not vacated within five years of Deed of Trust.

anchor.surface_text: As the premises were number vacated within five years of the execution of the Deed of Trust,

facts.text: Plaintiffs filed suit on July 28, 1959 for ejectment and Rs. 7,163/12/3 arrears from August 1956 to July 1959.

anchor.surface_text: the plaintiff-respondents after serving numberice of demand filed the present suit on July 28, 1959 against the Board of Trustees r. K. Ghoshs Academy and other defendants. One of the reliefs claimed was for ejectment of the defendants from the premises in dispute. The other relief claimed was for recovery of Rs. 7,163/12/3

facts.text: Suit contested by defendants No. 2,3,7,12 as Managing Committee members; denied landlord-tenant, rent contract, claimed Deed fraudulent and school dedicated.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was companytested by defendants No. 2, 3, 7 and 12 in-their capacity as members of the Managing Committee. ... According to the companytesting defendants, there was numberrelationship of landlord and tenant between the plaintiffs and T. K. Ghoshs Academy and its Managing Committee. It was also stated that there was numbercontract to pay the rent of Rs. 287/8/- per month. The Deed of Trust was stated by the companytesting defendants to be fraudulent, illusory and void document.

facts.text: Trial court decreed suit, held Deed genuine and valid, tenancy exists.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt, as mentioned earlier, decreed the suit. It was held that the Deed of Trust was a genuine and valid document and was binding on the school and its Managing Committee. As regards the existence of the relationship of landlord and tenant, the trial companyrt held that the companytract of tenancy was evidenced by the Deed of Trust and was binding upon the parties.

facts.text: High Court rejected dedication claim, accepted tenancy but set aside ejectment for lack of s.106 notice, reduced amount to Rs. 3,725/2/- .

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected the companytention that there had been dedication of the school building. Likewise, the companytention that there did number arise the relationship of landlord and tenant between the parties was rejected. The High Court set aside the decree for ejectment because it was of the view that such decree companyld be awarded only after determination of the tenancy by giving a numberice under section 106 of the Transfer of Property Act. The High Court further reduced the amount

facts.text: Supreme Court held appeal maintainable under Article 133(1)(b).

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the appeal is maintainable under article 133 1  b  of the Constitution.

facts.text: School treated as proprietary school till execution of Deed of Trust on August 13, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Coming to the merits of the appeal, we find that till the execution of the Deed of Trust on August 13, 1950, the school in question was treated as a proprietary school.

facts.text: Inspection note dated December 10, 1947 stated institution was proprietary school.

anchor.surface_text: This is clear from the inspection numbere dated December 10, 1947 of the Inspector of Schools. According to the inspection numbere, this institution was a proprietary school

facts.text: Annual statement dated January 8, 1950 mentioned proprietors as plaintiff-respondents.

anchor.surface_text: In the annual statement dated January 8, 1950 relating to the school which had to be furnished by the school authorities to the Board of Secondary Education, it was mentioned that the proprietors of the school were the plaintiff-respondents.

facts.text: Deed of Trust excluded land and building from trust property.

anchor.surface_text: The Trust Deed, however, made it clear that the land and building wherein the school was located did number form part of the trust property.

facts.text: Managing Committee received deficit grants from Government based on house rent Rs. 250 + Rs. 37.50 per month.

anchor.surface_text: It has been proved upon the material on record that the Managing Committee has been receiving deficit grants from the Government on the basis of statements showing house rent payable by it for school building to be Rs. 250 plus Rs. 37.50 per month.

facts.text: Managing Committee resolution on December 23, 1954 admitted rent of Rs. 287.50 for school premises.

anchor.surface_text: In addition to that, we find that the Managing Committee in its resolution passed in the meeting held on December 23, 1954 admitted that an amount of Rs. 287.50 was to be paid as rent to the proprietors for the school premises including the portion in the occupation of the headmaster.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld High Court decree for recovery of Rs. 3,725/2/- .

anchor.surface_text: In view of the above material, we find numbercogent ground to interfere with the judgment of the High Court maintaining decree for recovery of money to the extent of Rs. 3,725/2/- in favour of the plaintiff-respondents.
under article 133 1 b of the Constitution.

concepts.interpretation: Applicable where the High Court judgment, decree or final order involves directly or indirectly some claim or question respecting property of the value of not less than twenty thousand rupees, even if it is not the subject-matter of the dispute and the decree is not one of affirmance.

concepts.interpretation: Requires the amount or value of the subject-matter of the dispute in the court of first instance and still in dispute on appeal to be not less than twenty thousand rupees.

arguments.claim: High Court judgment not one of affirmance as set aside ejectment and reduced amount.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the High Court in the present case plainly did not affirm the decision of the trial court because the High Court set aside the decree for ejectment and also reduced the amount for the recovery of which decree had been awarded by the trial court.

arguments.court_reasoning: Cites Tirumalachetti Rajaram: look at decree entirety.

arguments.claim: Clause (b) applies to claim/question re property >20k even indirectly, distinct from subject-matter under (a).

anchor.surface_text: Perusal of clause b of article 133 1 shows that an appeal shall lie to this Court from any judgment, decree or final order in a civil proceeding of a High Court if the High Court certifies that the judgment, decree or final order involves directly or indirectly some claim or question respecting property of the value of not less than twenty thousand rupees.

arguments.claim: School premises value >20k; claim re occupation without rent vs liability.

anchor.surface_text: As would appear from the resume of facts given earlier, the case of the plaintiffs was that the defendants were liable to pay rent for being in occupation of the school premises. As against that, the case of the defendant-appellants was that they were entitled to occupy the said premises for carrying on the school without payment of rent.

holdings.text: the appeal is maintainable under article 133 1 b of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the appeal is maintainable under article 133 1 b of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court judgment involves claim or question respecting school premises valued over Rs. 20,000 indirectly, distinct from subject-matter under clause (a); not a judgment of affirmance as varied trial court decree by setting aside ejectment and reducing amount; cites precedents distinguishing clauses (a) and (b).

holdings.text: There is, in our opinion, no force in this contention that no liability for payment of rent can be fastened upon the defendants

anchor.surface_text: It has been argued on behalf of the appellants that no liability for payment of rent can be fastened upon the defendants and that the High Court was in error in holding to the contrary. There is, in our opinion, no force in this contention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: School treated as proprietary until 1950; trust deed excludes land and building from trust property; managing committee received government deficit grants based on rent statements of Rs. 287.50; committee resolution of 1954 admits rent liability; audit report mentions rent.

holdings.text: we find no cogent ground to interfere with the judgment of the High Court maintaining decree for recovery of money to the extent of Rs. 3,725/2/- in favour of the plaintiff-respondents

anchor.surface_text: In view of the above material, we find no cogent ground to interfere with the judgment of the High Court maintaining decree for recovery of money to the extent of Rs. 3,725/2/- in favour of the plaintiff-respondents.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Material on record including government grants on rent basis, managing committee resolution admitting Rs. 287.50 rent, and audit report establish rent liability and tenancy relationship evidenced by trust deed.

holdings.text: the present case did not fall under clause a of article 133 1

anchor.surface_text: The present case did number fall under clause a of article 133 1 because it companyld number be said that the amount or value of the subject-matter of the dispute was number less than twenty thousand rupees.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdictional value of suit (ejectment plus Rs. 7,163 arrears and 12 months rent) less than Rs. 20,000; clause (a) requires subject-matter value not less than Rs. 20,000 still in dispute on appeal.

holdings.text: the judgment of the High Court in the present case plainly did number affirm the decision of the trial court

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the High Court in the present case plainly did number affirm the decision of the trial companyrt because the High Court set aside the decree for ejectment and also reduced the amount for the recovery of which decree had been awarded by the trial companyrt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court varied trial court decree by setting aside ejectment and reducing decreed amount; affirmance determined by decree entirety, not partial variation in favor of appellant; cites Tirumalachetti Rajaram precedent.

precedents.citation: Tirumalachetti Rajaram v. Tirumalachetti Radhakrishnayya Chetty 1

anchor.surface_text: As observed by the Constitution Bench of this Court in the case of Tirumalachetti Rajaram v. Tirumalachetti Radhakrishnayya Chetty 1 , in determining the character of the appellate decree we have to look at the appellate decree taken in its entirety and companypare it with the decision of the trial

precedents.case_name: Tirumalachetti Rajaram v. Tirumalachetti Radhakrishnayya Chetty
precedents.cited_proposition: In determining the character of the appellate decree, look at the appellate decree taken in its entirety and compare it with the decision of the trial court as a whole to decide if it is one of affirmance; nature of variation irrelevant
precedents.cited_holding: in determining the character of the appellate decree we have to look at the appellate decree taken in its entirety and compare it with the decision of the trial court as a whole and decide whether the appellate decree is one of affirmance or not. In this enquiry the nature of the variation made whether it is in favour of the intending appellant or otherwise, would not be relevant

precedents.citation: Chhitarmal v. M s Shah Pannalal Chandulal 1

anchor.surface_text: If in a proposed appeal there is no claim or question raised respecting property other than the subject-matter, clause a will apply if there is involved in the appeal a claim or question respecting property of an amount or value not less than Rs. 20,000 in addition to or other than the subject-matter of the dispute clause b will apply see Chhitarmal v. M s Shah Pannalal Chandulal 1

precedents.case_name: Chhitarmal v. M s Shah Pannalal Chandulal
precedents.cited_proposition: Clause (b) of Article 133(1) applies to claims or questions respecting property other than or in addition to the subject-matter of the dispute valued at not less than Rs. 20,000

precedents.citation: Surapati Roy Ors. v. Ram Narayan Mukherji Ors. 2

anchor.surface_text: We may in this context refer to a decision of the Judicial Committee in the case of Surapati Roy Ors. v. Ram Narayan Mukherji Ors. 2 . Question which arose in that case was regarding the validity of a certificate granted by the High Court under section 110 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

precedents.case_name: Surapati Roy Ors. v. Ram Narayan Mukherji Ors.
precedents.cited_proposition: Certificate of fitness valid where subject-matter relates to recurring liability in respect of property considerably above appealable value
precedents.cited_holding: The subject matter in dispute relates to a recurring liability and is in respect of a property considerably above the appealable value. The certificate in the circumstances is quite in order.

precedents.cited_proposition: Certificate under Article 133(1)(b) not proper merely for recurring liability without claim or question respecting property of value not less than Rs. 20,000
